Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: This is a civil action brought by Plaintiff, Jessica Taylor (“Plaintiff”), against her landlord, Mark Stevens (“Defendant”), for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 21.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 21, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $7,000, and venue is proper because the leased premises are located in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts.

State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. \u00a7 4.proposition: Between approximately November 10, 2025, and December 1, 2025, the Premises remained without hot water, constituting a violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.190, which requires that every dwelling unit have an adequate supply of hot water at all times.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from substantial interference with their tenancy, even when the landlord’s acts or omissions are negligent rather than intentional.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects any requirement of intent and holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when substantial interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling, and applies that rule to noise conditions the landlords negligently allowed to persist, finding a violation and constructive eviction. This directly supports the proposition that negligent acts or omissions can violate quiet enjoyment if they substantially interfere with tenancy.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The absence of essential services such as hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14, which covers two distinct grounds: (1) willful failure to provide essential services (explicitly listing ‘water, hot water, heat,’ etc.) and (2) interference with quiet enjoyment. The opinion treats these as separate statutory bases and analyzes ‘quiet enjoyment’ by reference to interference from flooding and unsanitary conditions, not absence of hot water or other essential services. It nowhere holds or suggests that lack of essential services itself is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; thus it does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “[G. L. c. 186, § 14] imposes civil and criminal liability on a landlord that ‘willfully or intentionally’ fails to provide essential services that it is obligated to furnish, or ‘directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.’ … When § 14 was first enacted, both categories of prohibited conduct — failure to provide services and interference with quiet enjoyment — were modified by the words ‘willfully or intentionally.’ … [T]he requirement of intentional conduct was retained for failure to provide essential services, but deleted from the quiet enjoyment clause….”

*Dartmouth Consumer Group v. Town of Dar.raw_text: *Dartmouth Consumer Group v. Town of Dartmouth*, 384 Mass. 255 (1981)
*Dartmouth Consumer Group v. Town of Dar.proposition: The absence of essential services such as hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Dartmouth Consumer Group v. Town of Dar.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a criminal case about a murder conviction and jury selection issues; it does not concern landlord-tenant law, habitability, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. There is no discussion of essential services, hot water, or any breach of quiet enjoyment. Therefore this case cannot be authority for the proposition that the absence of hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Dartmouth Consumer Group v. Town of Dar.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt: the opinion concerns a homicide prosecution (Reid) and issues of peremptory challenges, sufficiency of the evidence, jury instructions, and evidentiary rulings, and does not address landlord–tenant law or quiet enjoyment.]

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain hot water violated the State Sanitary Code and thereby constituted a breach per se of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that loss of heat and hot water that violates the State Sanitary Code constitutes a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability and allows rent abatement, but it does not frame this as a per se breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court’s analysis is expressly about the warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not about quiet enjoyment or a per se rule linking sanitary code violations (like failure to maintain hot water) to breach of that separate covenant. Thus, the case does not support the proposition as stated.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201).”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain hot water violated the State Sanitary Code and thereby constituted a breach per se of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This excerpt (a concurrence/dissent) focuses on implying a landlord obligation based on violations of the State Sanitary Code and interdependence of rent and repair duties; it does not frame the violation as a breach per se of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The discussion is about implied warranty/contractual obligations, not about quiet enjoyment, and it expressly ties the landlord’s duties to statutory and code standards rather than to that covenant. Nothing here states that failure to maintain hot water, or any Code violation, automatically constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The protections afforded by G.L. c. 186, § 14 apply regardless of Defendant’s intent where the interference is substantial and renders the premises less fit to live in.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that for a G.L. c. 186, § 14 quiet enjoyment claim, the landlord’s intent is not required; the landlord’s conduct and its natural and probable consequences control. The opinion applies that principle to a substantial interference (failure to provide heat) that clearly made the premises less fit to live in, and rejects the landlord’s financial inability as a defense. Thus it supports the proposition that § 14 protections apply regardless of intent where the interference substantially impairs habitability.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… Thus… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14… and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct is also inconsistent with the implied warranty of habitability recognized in *Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, and further supports a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184,.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent, not the majority, and it actually criticizes and attempts to narrow the majority’s formulation of an implied warranty of habitability rather than embracing it as a broad principle. While Hemingway as a whole is the seminal Massachusetts case recognizing an implied warranty of habitability, this specific text does not itself recognize or expand that warranty, nor does it connect it to quiet enjoyment. Using this passage as authority that Hemingway recognized an implied warranty of habitability supporting a quiet-enjoyment breach is therefore inaccurate.
Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184,.relevant_excerpt: "I dissent from the statement of such a broad and sweeping new rule for the reason, in part, that it would be sufficient for the decision of these cases to hold that the landlord, in renting the apartments to the tenants, impliedly agreed that the apartments would comply with the several requirements of the Code which the tenants allege were violated... I dissent from the stated new rule for the further reason that the basis and scope of the landlord’s obligation thereunder are related to the court’s implication of a new and otherwise undefined warranty of fitness of the rented premises for human habitation."

*Khan v. Elkman*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 968.proposition: Defendant’s conduct is also inconsistent with the implied warranty of habitability recognized in *Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184, and further supports a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment.

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Persistent failure to provide hot water has been recognized as a violation of both the State Sanitary Code and G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does address the landlord’s obligation to provide heat and hot water and interprets the State Sanitary Code provisions requiring a written agreement to shift that obligation to the tenant. However, the case does not involve or discuss a factual scenario of persistent failure to provide hot water, nor does it mention G.L. c. 186, § 14 or hold that such failure constitutes a violation of that statute. It therefore cannot be cited as authority that persistent lack of hot water has been recognized as a violation of both the State Sanitary Code and G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The tenant maintains that under the State Sanitary Code the landlord is not excused from his obligation to provide heat and hot water unless there is a writing transferring the obligation to the tenant. The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Persistent failure to provide hot water has been recognized as a violation of both the State Sanitary Code and G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion in Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis concerns whether a violation of the lead paint statute automatically constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds that it does not absent at least negligent conduct by the landlord. It does not discuss hot water, the State Sanitary Code provisions regarding hot water, or recognize lack of hot water as a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about persistent failure to provide hot water.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A (Defenses and cou.raw_text: G.L. c. 239, § 8A (Defenses and counterclaims in eviction proceedings)
G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A (Defenses and cou.proposition: G.L. c. 239, § 8A (Defenses and counterclaims in eviction proceedings)
